unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post about dates and times in the news, formatted as requested:
normalised: I remember reading a particularly confusing news report back in two thousand and eight, during the Mumbai terror attacks. The initial reports were chaotic, obviously, but the way the times were presented made it even harder to follow. One channel was using twenty four hour format, stating something happened at fourteen thirty hours, while another reported the same event at two thirty P-M. To someone not paying close attention, it sounded like completely different times.

unnormalised: I remember reading a particularly confusing news report back in '08, during the Mumbai terror attacks. The initial reports were chaotic, obviously, but the way the times were presented made it even harder to follow. One channel was using 24-hr format, stating something happened at 14:30 hrs, while another reported the same event at 2:30 PM. To someone not paying close attention, it sounded like completely different times.
normalised: Later, I noticed how different news outlets handled dates. For example, some international news organizations would write "September eleventh, two thousand and one" as "eleventh September two thousand and one," which is perfectly fine, but it caused me to pause for a moment because I'm more accustomed to the U-S style here in India. I distinctly remember reading an article where they referred to the attack on "seventh July two thousand and five" and needing to quickly convert that to July seventh in my head. It became second nature eventually, but during that initial news deluge, the inconsistencies felt disruptive.

unnormalised: Later, I noticed how different news outlets handled dates. For example, some international news organizations would write "September 11, 2001" as "11 September 2001," which is perfectly fine, but it caused me to pause for a moment because I'm more accustomed to the US style here in India. I distinctly remember reading an article where they referred to the attack on "7/7/2005" and needing to quickly convert that to July 7th in my head. It became second nature eventually, but during that initial news deluge, the inconsistencies felt disruptive.
normalised: And don't even get me started on deadlines. I once saw a report about a bridge construction project being "delayed until thirty first December two thousand and twenty four", which initially gave me a sense of relief, until I realized they meant the last day of the year and not sometime in March as my brain had auto-filled.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on deadlines. I once saw a report about a bridge construction project being "delayed until 31/12/2024", which initially gave me a sense of relief, until I realized they meant the last day of the year and not sometime in March as my brain had auto-filled..
normalised: Even now, with digital media being so prevalent, these discrepancies persist. A headline might say, "P-M Modi's address today at ten zero zero," but does that mean ten zero zero A-M or ten zero zero P-M? Usually, the context clears it up, but that initial second of uncertainty is always there.

unnormalised: Even now, with digital media being so prevalent, these discrepancies persist. A headline might say, "PM Modi's address today at 10:00," but does that mean 10:00 AM or 10:00 PM? Usually, the context clears it up, but that initial second of uncertainty is always there.
normalised: Think about sports reporting too. They love throwing around dates. "India versus Pakistan, World Cup Final, twenty eighth March two thousand and eleven." Perfectly straightforward, but imagine if that were presented in a different way – say, "March twenty eighth, two thousand and eleven." Suddenly, it's less clear and requires a bit more mental processing.

unnormalised: Think about sports reporting too. They love throwing around dates. "India vs. Pakistan, World Cup Final, 28/03/2011." Perfectly straightforward, but imagine if that were presented in a different way – say, "March 28th, '11." Suddenly, it's less clear and requires a bit more mental processing.
normalised: The problem compounds when dealing with historical news. I was reading about the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, which took place on "thirteenth April nineteen nineteen". But that would need to be easily adapted for different audiences and media formats - not to mention localized. I wish all news agencies could develop guidelines on presenting Dates and Times or follow the I-S-O eight thousand six hundred and one date and time format for communicating the exact information unambiguously. It would really help prevent so much confusion, especially in sensitive situations.

normalised: Finally, the sheer volume of data makes it hard to keep up. The sheer amount of content from local media versus national media versus international media creates different norms for presenting the data, so I wish they would all get on the same page.
